div1.p: Howard comments on Kean's account of the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from L.O. Howard to Jefferson Randolph Kean, March 29, 1928
div1.opener:
Ans.
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
BUREAU OF ENTOMOLOGY
WASHINGTON, D. C.
March 29, 1928.
Colonel J. R. Kean,
Army Medical Museum,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Kean:
div1.p:
Dr. Fenton B. Turck has just handed me a copy of the March num-
ber of The Military Surgeon which contains as its leading article your
very admirable address made at the dedication of Walter Reed's birth-
place. I understand that you gave him this copy for me, and I thank
you for it very sincerely. I am greatly pleased to notice the refer-
ence to Reed's letter to me of January 13, 1901.

It is immensely interesting to read the story of the man as you
knew him personally, beginning on page 296. Your own story is personal
and authoritative. You knew the man and you were on the spot with him.
The account of your interview with General Wood in Reed's company is very
striking.

Your paragraph at the bottom of page 302, in which you compare
Finlay with A. F. A. King, is very strong.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, L. O. Howard
Senior Entomologist. loh-wft
P.S. By the way, do you know my “Sketch History of Medical Ento-
mology,” published in the Jubilee Volume of the American Public Health
Association and afterwards reprinted in the Smithsonian Report? If not,
I will send you a separate from the latter report.
